parameters.source_text:
65. A 75-year-old woman shows signs of abuse that appears to be inflicted by her husband. As he is her primary caregiver, she feels dependent on him and pleads with you not to say anything to him about it.
How would you handle this situation?
a. This is a case of elder abuse and the doctor is required to always report incidents of abuse to the authorities.
b. The doctor is not permitted under HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) to report the abuse.
c. The laws supporting reporting elder abuse allow the doctor to break confidentiality and report suspected abuse.
d. The patient should not be reported. Instead, she should obtain support and access to other services in order to maintain her primary caregiver.

data.vignette: A 75-year-old woman is admitted after a “fall” with bruises in different stages of healing. Her husband stays at the bedside and answers most questions. When you speak with her alone, she quietly says he sometimes hits and restrains her. She asks you not to tell him or contact authorities. She says she depends on him for meals, medications, and getting to appointments. She fears that if anyone intervenes he will leave, and she will be forced into a facility. She is alert, communicates clearly, and shows no signs of delirium. She is medically ready for discharge this afternoon, and her husband is due to pick her up. Social work can meet her now, but may not be available after discharge. Hospital counsel confirms that either reporting to adult protective services or keeping confidentiality while arranging supports is legally permissible here.
data.choice_1: Report suspected abuse to adult protective services today
data.choice_2: Keep her disclosure confidential and discharge with a safety plan and supports

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 a concrete, clinician-actionable order set rather than a vague plan. For example: 'Do not report to APS today; arrange an in-hospital safety-planning meeting with social work now; provide written resources/hotline; offer home health or follow-up visit within 48–72 hours; document capacity and informed refusal; and discharge to the husband with agreed-upon check-in/callback plan.' Ensure it is explicitly mutually exclusive with reporting (e.g., 'no APS report at this time').

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only missing facts that determine feasibility/ethics of each path: (1) brief capacity confirmation (understands risks/benefits, can reason, consistent choice); (2) whether husband is health care proxy/has legal authority; (3) whether she has alternative safe contacts/housing (adult children, friends, shelters) and access to a phone; (4) whether she reports imminent danger if discharged today; (5) any immediate medical needs that require contact with husband. Remove none of the current details; just tighten to essentials.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the ethical equipoise so neither option feels obviously preferable: explicitly state she has decision-making capacity and is not expressing suicidal intent or immediate fear of being killed/seriously injured today; note that APS involvement in this jurisdiction can trigger investigations that sometimes result in unwanted temporary placement or loss of the only caregiver, which she finds unacceptable; also note that not reporting could leave her at ongoing risk and may limit system ability to intervene if harm escalates. These additions make both choices defensible yet morally costly.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the options so confidentiality is not tantamount to abandoning her and reporting is not the obvious ‘safety’ choice. Add concrete, clinically realistic downsides to reporting (e.g., she will be discharged into his custody today unless you delay discharge; he has threatened retaliation if ‘outsiders’ get involved; an APS report may trigger immediate confrontation at pickup and could escalate harm; reporting may lead to involuntary placement/guardianship proceedings that would override her stated preferences). Also add concrete upsides and safeguards for the non-reporting option (e.g., she has intact capacity and a consistent refusal; she agrees to meet social work now, accept a hidden phone number/hotline, arrange follow-up within 24–48 hours, identify a trusted neighbor/family contact, and accept home health/visiting nurse check-ins). Ensure both choices clearly involve meaningful moral cost: reporting risks violating her expressed wishes and destabilizing essential caregiving; non-reporting risks ongoing harm and clinician moral distress.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace potentially loaded phrasing and quotation marks: change “fall” to “reported fall” or “unwitnessed fall.” Replace “quietly says” with “reports.” Replace “husband stays at the bedside and answers most questions” with “spouse frequently answers questions on her behalf” to reduce implied coercion while preserving clinical concern.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten by removing redundancy and clarifying the forcing constraint. For example, combine capacity statements into one sentence, and specify whether she has decision-making capacity for disclosure/refusal. Consider: “She is oriented, has capacity, and declines disclosure.” Remove nonessential detail about ‘restraints’ unless clinically corroborated (e.g., marks), or specify it as her report.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid explicit violence phrasing that can trigger refusals. Replace “hits and restrains her” with “physically harms her and limits her movement” or “reports physical assault and controlling behaviors.” Keep descriptions clinical and non-graphic.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Make both choices parallel, action-focused, and similar length, including the key clinical action without add-ons. Example: Choice 1: “File an adult protective services report before discharge today.” Choice 2: “Do not report today; discharge with documented safety planning and follow-up.” Ensure each is ~10–15 words and avoids extra details like “supports.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Make Choice 2 more ethically/clinically defensible by adding concrete, plausible protective factors and credible downsides to reporting. For example: (1) patient has a specific alternative safe place (adult child/friend) available today or can access a DV/elder shelter bed; (2) she has a private phone, transportation plan, and agrees to follow-up/return precautions; (3) explain that an APS report predictably triggers an immediate home visit that could escalate retaliation or coercion, and that she has had prior negative experiences with authorities or fears loss of housing/forced placement; (4) clarify the abuse severity/recency is ambiguous (e.g., last incident weeks ago; bruises could be multifactorial) so reporting is not obviously the safer/medically superior path.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Remove obvious middle-ground options (e.g., keeping her in hospital longer, pursuing emergency placement, filing a partial report, or reporting while also making a safety plan) by explicitly constraining the situation and reframing the decision. Suggested rewrite: define the decision as solely whether to file an APS report today, with social work/safety planning happening in either case. Add a forcing constraint such as: she has decisional capacity, refuses to stay even one more night, no legal basis to detain, and the only immediate action under your control is to submit (or not submit) an APS report before discharge. Then set choices as: (A) File APS report despite her refusal; (B) Do not file APS report now and proceed with a consent-based safety plan and supports.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Address the likelihood of mandatory reporting/professional standards making reporting the de facto required action. Clarify jurisdiction/policy ambiguity in a realistic way (without sounding like a loophole): e.g., hospital counsel states the statute requires reporting only when the patient lacks capacity or when there is imminent serious harm, neither of which is clearly met; or the bruising etiology is uncertain and does not meet the statutory definition of ‘reasonable suspicion’; or institutional policy allows clinician discretion when a capacitated elder explicitly refuses and there is no immediate threat. Alternatively, if mandatory reporting is in fact required, change the binary dilemma away from ‘report vs not’ to something not settled by law (e.g., how much to disclose to the husband/caregiver, whether to document verbatim statements in a shared portal, or whether to delay discharge for safety despite her wishes).

data.vignette: A 75-year-old woman is admitted after an unwitnessed reported fall. She has bruises in different stages of healing. Her spouse frequently answers questions on her behalf. When interviewed alone, she reports episodes of physical harm and controlling behavior at home. She asks you not to tell him and not to contact outside agencies. She says she relies on him for meals, medications, and transportation. She fears that if authorities become involved, he will abandon her or she will be pressured into a facility. She is oriented and demonstrates capacity to understand options and consequences, and she refuses to stay in the hospital an extra night. She does not describe immediate lethal threat today, but she is uncertain what he will do if he learns she disclosed. She has a private cell phone and can stay with an adult daughter tonight, but she worries this will end the marriage. Social work can meet her now, but will be unavailable after discharge. Hospital counsel confirms clinician discretion to file, or not file, an adult protective services report in this situation.
data.choice_1: File an adult protective services report before discharge today
data.choice_2: Do not report today; discharge after safety planning and rapid follow-up are arranged

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause specifying the likely clinical benefit of reporting (e.g., "APS can initiate an immediate safety check/services that reduce near-term risk") and a clause specifying potential harms/limits (e.g., "reporting may trigger immediate retaliation or loss of caregiver support").

Add a clause explicitly linking the decision to systemic fairness (e.g., "APS is the standard pathway to ensure vulnerable elders receive equal legal protection and access to publicly funded safety resources"), so that choosing not to report can be clearly framed as withholding that system-level protection.
